climbs.name: Wild as You Want To Be

content.description:
In my opinion, this is one of the best 5.11's in Lander, and a must do at Wolf Point.

Head up easy lower angle terrain on great rock littered with crimps and finger swallowing pockets. At the end of the slab, pick your way up good holds on the face to a rest before the overhang.

The last part of the climb follows sinker pockets on the blackened dolomite up and out the overhang. Super fun, and a great 1st pitch of the day.
content.protection: Fully equipped with permadraws and lowering hooks
content.location: Just to the right of Dominant Species. Starts right by the small pine

content.description: The extension to Call of the Wild. It adds four bolts of pumpy small hold climbing.  The prevailing beta is to skip the second and third bolt as there are not very good holds to clip from.  I know from (way too much) experience that this can end in a 40 footer.
content.location: Left side of the cave, shared start with Bark at the Moon

content.description: Starts in the middle of the cave, up a shared start where about 8 or 9 routes begin.  At bolt three, trend left following a seam with lie backs and jugs.  You come to a roof at bolt 8 and continue on the right line of draws.  The crux occurs here, followed by a total of six more draws to a two bolt anchor at about 100 feet.  There is a difficult extension above called "God of War."  It was climbed by BJ Tilden in the fall of 2017 at 5.14c.
content.protection: Around 14 bolts, fixed with steel draws.

content.description: Start in the middle of the cave, at the shared start. At bolt three trend up and left, following a seam to bolt 8. Here you continue left and follow 5 more bolts up the steep headwall, finishing at an anchor at two thirds height. This route shares the first eight bolts with Romulus before trending left, and it is 13a to that point where there is a good rest. The redpoint crux is entering the upper headwall section with a long dead point to a large jug. Expect pumpy climbing above this.
content.protection: About 13 bolts with fixed steel cable draws
content.location: Starts at an obvious shared start.  There are actually two sets of bolts at the beginning of all these routes, you clip the left draws for this route so that more than one climber can be in the wall at the same time.

climbs.name: Reemed Out
climbs.fa: Jonathan Siegrist, equipped by Tom Rangitsch

content.description: Extension to Remus, gaining a clean face above the first anchor.  The character of the climb changes from steep jugs to technical face climbing.  You follow a seem, lay backing and using the occasional pocket.  After several bolts you trend left to a blunt arete.  There is a hard crux here, using small holds and tricky footwork.  You end up in a dihedral for the last two bolts, fighting the pump to get you (finally) to the chains
content.protection: bolts, fixed with cable draws.  There are about 20 total.  also be very careful lowering as you only have about 2 feet left on an 80 meter rope when the climber reaches the ground
content.location: left side of the cave, starts at the shared start and goes left at every point where you have a choice.

content.description: Gently overhanging at the beginning, this one starts with sustained pockets and side pulls.  It is pretty cruxy until bolt 5.  Next the angle lessens, the rock gets more featured (or chossy if you like), and you can recover.  It gets steeper again and there is a pretty long move to enter the overhanging headwall. This is followed by sustained moves as the bulge rounds out. Expect one more crux before the anchor.
content.location: Left side of the Wolf Point main area, just outside of the cave proper.  It starts on yellowish stone which is high quality and well featured.

content.description: Extension to Bark at the Moon.  Continue up past the anchor on that route, following a dihedral on crimps and gastons for three bolts.  Move slightly right up pockets and a shouldery lay back to long cranks on small pockets and edges.  Technical climbing with a pump carried on from the 12c first pitch.  You need an 80 meter rope to lower off this pitch to the ground.  Alternately you can lower twice with a sixty.
content.protection: Bolts. The first pitch is fixed with stainless cable draws. The extension is 5 more bolts.
content.location: Right side of the main cave feature.

content.description: Starts on a slab for the first six bolts.  Climb easy terrain to the steep upper section, then hang on for seven more bolts.  The crux is the last two bolts with a small right hand crimp to take you to the last horizontal, followed by a couple strenuous pulls to the anchor.
content.location: Right side of the cliff, outside of the cave proper and around a corner.  Look for a large detached flake at the bottom where the route begins.

content.description: Shares the start with Bark at the Moon, up plated rock on the right apron of the main cave. At bolt six move slightly left and continue up for 7 more bolts. The main difficulty consists of fighting the pump on juggy pockets that bring you to a crux off a small 2 finger left hand and then a big move to a jug. The anchor is at about 100 feet.  I personally like this route better than Bark at the Moon.
content.protection: 13 or so bolts, with fixed cable draws

climbs.name: The Beholder
climbs.fa: BJ Tilden, 2014.  equipped by Steve Bechtel

content.description: Sustained climbing in the center of the cave.  Start up the shared layback crack for three bolts and move slightly right, aiming for a small roof at bolt 6.  The crux of the climb starts here, with big moves to good pockets and edges.  A brief shake on jugs at bolt 8 prepares you for a long crank off a shallow right hand key hole with poor feet.  This hold is best as a first team two finger stack.  You get into a good undercling rest at this point, and then have 3 more bolts up a shallow dihedral.  The rock above the undercling is not as good as the rest of the route, but the climbing is somewhat easier.
content.location: Shared start in the center/left of the cave.

content.description: Right side of the cave.  Start up plated vertical rock for 6 bolts to a rest just before the steeps.  This section is probably mid 5.11.  Tackle a few bouldery moves here, entering the steep headwall above to jug hauling fun.  The crux is from the last bolt to the chains, invoking a crank off a sinker left hand two finger to a small right hand crimp and then a big move with the left hand to the finishing jug.  Full value for the grade.
content.protection: Around 14 bolts, this one has fixed steel hardware
